column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column7: The Chairman of the Remuneration and Nominations Committee is John Eales, an independent Non-Executive Director. The role of the Committee is to make recommendations to the Board about Magellan's remuneration framework for directors and induction programs for directors; the development and implementation of a process for evaluating the performance of the Board, its committees and directors; the selection, appointment and re-election of directors; and Board succession plans.

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: The Chairman of the Board is Andrew Formica, an independent Non-Executive Director. He is not the Company's chief executive officer.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column7: The Board is responsible for the operation and stewardship of Magellan and its overall success, long-term growth, and corporate governance. The Board has approved a formal Charter which details its role, powers, duties and functions.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column7: Management is responsible for implementing the strategic objectives and operating within the risk appetite set by the Board and for all other aspects of Magellan's day-to-day running. Management is also responsible for providing the Board with accurate, timely and precise information to enable the Board to perform its responsibilities.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column7: Magellan's Board has ultimate oversight over risk management and compliance, including setting Magellan's risk appetite about critical risks, including environmental risk. The Board considers the Group's appetite for ecological risk on at least an annual basis as part of its periodic review of Magellan's risk management framework. In 2023, Magellan adopted a new Risk Management Framework for climate-related risks and opportunities.

As a fiduciary, Magellan has a duty of care, loyalty, honesty and good faith to act in the best interests of its clients. Compliance with this duty can be achieved by trying to avoid conflicts of interest and by fully disclosing all material facts concerning any conflict that does arise. Applicable Persons must be careful to avoid placing themselves in a position where there would be an actual or potential conflict of interest, or a reasonable perception of an actual or potential conflict of interest, between the interests of Magellan (or their duties to Magellan) and its clients and any personal or external business interests (or duties).

An investor relations program has been designed to facilitate effective two-way communication with investors. The program includes half-yearly and annual results briefings, the ability to submit questions via the website and a formal process for submitting questions to be answered at the Annual General Meeting.

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column7: The Board seeks to balance skills, knowledge, and experience to direct and oversee Magellan's activities. The Board considers that collectively, the Directors have an appropriate range of skills, experience, and expertise to understand and competently deal with current and emerging business issues, effectively monitor and review Magellan's performance, and exercise independent judgment.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column7: The Board's Charter requires the Board to review its performance and the performance of its Committees and Directors every two years. The review considers the Board's role, the processes of the Board and its Committees, and the collective and individual performance of the Board, its Committees, and each Director. The review may be conducted through written and oral communications and is discussed by the whole Board. An individual Director's performance is considered when the Board determines whether or not to support the Director for re-election. A performance evaluation using the above process was last undertaken in August 2023.

column7: At Magellan, our investment team diligently engages with companies on Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) risks and opportunities to strengthen our conviction in portfolio risk management and improve investment outcomes.

Magellan is committed to responsible investment. At Magellan, successful investing is about identifying and owning, for the long-term, companies that can sustainably generate excess returns on capital for years to come. As long-term owners, we aim to act as responsible stewards of our client's investments by integrating Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) issues into our investment process, exercising our proxy voting rights and having an open dialogue with portfolio companies on various topics.

In 2023, as part of Magellan's commitment to the Net Zero Asset Manager Initiative (NZAMi), we enhanced the alignment assessment to net zero for all investee companies utilising the net zero investment framework (NZIF). Where an investee company does not have a net zero target, science-based targets or a credible strategy, we will prioritise engagement, particularly for the high-emitting sectors.

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column7: Climate change is an increasingly important issue for global companies and investors, potentially affecting business models through government regulation (e.g. carbon pricing), technology and consumption patterns. Notably, there are also significant opportunities for companies to profitably deploy capital into areas that meet the needs of a decarbonising world. These factors, directly and indirectly, impact the relative cost of companies' products and services, customer demand and pricing power.
